headline: Man Gets 3 Years in French Heist Case
summary: Toni Musulin, the French armored-car driver who last year vanished with more than $14 million and turned himself in a few days later, was found guilty of theft and sentenced to three years in prison.

headline: Firms Trade Blame Over Oil Spill
summary: Executives of the three main companies connected with the Gulf of Mexico oil spill pointed fingers at each other in Senate testimony, as lawmakers criticized them and federal offshore-drilling regulators.

headline: New York Area Crime Blotter
summary: A roundup of area police and court activity.

headline: Google Searches for a Use for Its Cash
summary: The Internet search giant has a hard choice to make: return cash to shareholders or start investing in higher-growth but lower-return businesses.

headline: Hold Off Being Bullish on Luxury in China
summary: A KPMG survey of wealthy Chinese consumers found three-quarters of respondents said the financial downturn had little impact on them. But authors of the report say it's wise not to be "overly bullish" on the nation's luxury sector.

headline: A Cold War Site Turned Tourist Attraction
summary: At the Museum of the Strategic Rocket Troops in Pervomaisk, Ukraine, visitors can take a tour of an underground Soviet command post that once controlled 10 nuclear-tipped missiles.

headline: Bazaar: Taipei
summary: AsusTek's latest 3-D gaming laptop, priced around $2,500, has been a surprisingly popular item in a sluggish economy.

headline: Regulators Push for Market-Wide Circuit Breaker
summary: Securities regulators are seeking a market-wide "circuit breaker" tied to moves in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

headline: Hearing Raises Questions on Oil Watchdog
summary: An engineer for the agency that serves as a watchdog over the oil industry testified that he didn't know the agency's own regulations for a key piece of equipment designed to prevent an explosion on an offshore rig.

headline: Greater New York Watch
summary: A roundup of regional news

headline: Gold Reaches Record as Europeans Pile In
summary: The Dow fell slightly, and Nasdaq gained, but the most striking news was how Europeans, alarmed at the plunging value of their currency, led an exodus out of the euro and into gold.

headline: Home Prices Stabilizing
summary: Home prices appear to be stabilizing as demand for higher-priced homes picks up and distressed properties, still a large part of the market, are no longer changing hands at the deeply discounted prices of a year ago.

headline: J.P. Morgan Raises Stake in Gannett
summary: J.P. Morgan bought a 10.2% stake in Gannett, a $400 million vote of confidence in a traditional-media company.

headline: America's Scenic Drives
summary: Here are some of the scenic routes scouted out for auto makers -- from the mountains of Oregon to the grassy knolls of New York to the beaches of California.

headline: Sessions Sees Vote Before Recess
summary: Sen. Jeff Sessions said he believed the Senate could conclude consideration of Elena Kagan's candidacy for the Supreme Court before August recess.

headline: Prim and Proper Prime Rib
summary: A short train ride from Wall Street, Brooklyn's Peter Luger Steakhouse is a rite of passage for traders and tourists alike who want a red-meat lunch.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: Pound, Euro on Sale
summary: You might want to consider changing some of your dollars sooner rather than later, writes Brett Arends. Both fell a long way in the uncertainty leading into Sunday night's bailout, and that may not last.

headline: Videogame Maker Electronic Arts Swings to Profit
summary: Videogame maker Electronic Arts swung to a profit in its fourth quarter as revenue rose 14%, helped by strong sales of two new titles.

headline: Abbott in Licensing Deal With Indian Firm
summary: Abbott Laboratories entered into a licensing and supply agreement with Indian pharmaceutical company Zydus Cadila.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: In tonight's Europa League final, Fulham faces Atlético Madrid, the 6/5 favorite to win the match in 90 minutes with Boylesports.

headline: Gold Settles at All-Time High
summary: Gold set an all-time high, a symptom of broad-based investor concerns about markets and the global  economy.

headline: Biden's Son Has Mild Stroke
summary: Delaware Attorney General Beau Biden is expected to make a complete recovery, the hospital's medical director said.

headline: Chinese Stocks' Losses Grow
summary: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese shares slid as the fear of monetary tightening by Beijing resurfaced after economic data showing consumer and property prices continued to rise on the mainland. Most markets in Asia and Europe fell.

headline: Senate Testimony in Deepwater Horizon Rig Blast
summary: Representatives of the companies connected to the April 20 explosion on the Deepwater Horizon oil rig testified before the U.S. Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee Tuesday.

headline: Crude Slips With Storage Data on Tap
summary: Crude-oil futures prices posted modest losses while awaiting clear short-term direction from U.S. weekly oil inventory data.

headline: Small Price Gains In New York Area
summary: The National Association of Realtors reported on Tuesday that median home prices rose in 91 of 152 counties and metropolitan areas during the first quarter from a year earlier.

headline: Retirement-Plan Options for Business Owners
summary: You might count on selling the business to fund your golden years. But a better strategy is to set up a tax-advantaged retirement plan.

headline: Correlated Market Mayhem Demands Tighter Reins
summary: The past weeks have been another lesson in the  dangers of correlation: From Wall Street's 1,000-point plunge to  the wildfire-like spread of Greece's debt crisis, markets nowadays move in  tandem, leaving investors with nowhere to hide when things go south.

headline: Videogames,Telecom Units Lift Vivendi Profit Higher
summary: French entertainment and telecommunications company Vivendi reported higher first-quarter earnings driven mainly by its videogame and telecom businesses, and reaffirmed its full-year outlook.

headline: Prudential Presents an Investor Dilemma
summary: Prudential PLC is determined to plow on with its $35.5 billion AIA acquisition from American International Group. But regulatory concerns show it may be a tough battle.

headline: European Markets End Off Lows
summary: European stocks ended lower, but off session lows Tuesday, as upbeat U.S. stocks and news that the U.K. was close to forming a majority government helped dispel the nagging doubts surrounding the massive euro-zone rescue package.

headline: Corio Bulks Up With Property Purchases
summary: Dutch property group Corio is on a major acquisition drive to gain heft in European retail.

headline: House Plan Targets Child-Care Tax Credit
summary: A bill introduced in the House would give middle-class working parents a larger tax credit to offset child-care costs, following a similar proposal from Obama.

headline: Underlying Gilt Tensions
summary: Investors soaked up U.K. government bonds at auction Tuesday, but next week's gilt sale may provide a sterner test amid economic, political and market tensions.

headline: FCC Wants Alerts on Wireless Overages
summary: U.S. regulators are proposing new regulations on the wireless phone industry, which would require carriers to alert consumers if they've gone over their monthly data or text message allotments.

headline: Senate Adopts Fed Audit Amendment
summary: The Senate voted 96-0 to authorize an examination of the Federal Reserve's closely guarded emergency lending to financial institutions in the months surrounding the financial crisis.

headline: InterContinental's Net Doubles
summary: InterContinental Hotels said first-quarter profit doubled as the return of business travelers to high-end hotels drove its first positive revenue performance in 18 months.

headline: Kagan Backed Counterterror Policies
summary: Supreme Court nominee Elena Kagan criticized aspects of the Bush administration's war on terror but she has also advanced arguments for strong counterterrorism policies, leaving relatively little room for critics on the right to attack her.

headline: Senate Panel Convenes in Rig Case
summary: The different companies involved in the late April explosion at a Gulf of Mexico Oil rig pointed fingers Tuesday in testimony before Congress.

headline: IMF: Russia May Grow Faster
summary: The International Monetary Fund said it may boost its forecast for Russian economic growth in 2010, as the country enjoys growing foreign reserves and suffers little from concerns about European sovereign debt.

headline: Navistar Gets Big Truck Order From J.B. Hunt
summary: Navistar International Corp. said it received an order from J.B. Hunt Transport Services to supply more than 5,000 heavy-duty commercial trucks through 2014.

headline: Deadly Tornadoes Hit Southern Plains
summary: Several tornadoes killed five people and injured dozens more in Oklahoma and Kansas on Monday.

headline: Wal-Mart Taps New Asda CEO
summary: Wal-Mart has appointed Andy Clarke as the new president and chief executive of U.K. supermarket chain Asda.

headline: EasyJet Cuts Outlook
summary: Budget carrier easyJet posted a narrower net loss in the fiscal first half, but said it was cutting profit targets for the year because of the disruption to air travel caused by the volcanic ash cloud from Iceland.

headline: Merck to Seek Drug Approvals
summary: Merck plans to file five new drug applications this year but said it has ended development of its first stab at a follow-on biologic drug, illustrating the risks of this emerging field.

headline: Australia Forecasts Faster Return to Surplus
summary: Australia's budget should return to surplus three years sooner than expected and before any other major advanced economy, the government said, helped by demand for its commodity exports.

headline: Ranbaxy Posts a Profit
summary: Ranbaxy Laboratories posted a first-quarter net profit of $213.2 million, compared with a net loss a year earlier on a large foreign-exchange loss.

headline: Pakistan Textile Workers Rally
summary: Thousands of Pakistanti textile and garment workers took to the streets Tuesday in Faisalabad and other cities to call for an immediate ban on yarn and cotton exports as a global cotton shortage has forced some textile factories into bankruptcy.

headline: BA's Striking Good Value
summary: British Airways investors can be reasonably confident that the Unite trade union stands little chance of stopping management's cost-cutting plans.

headline: Oil-Spill Cleanup Continues
summary: Crews remain on the lookout for oil residue in Alabama and Louisiana after the April 20 oil-rig blast in the Gulf of Mexico. Meanwhile, the different companies involved are pointing fingers in the incident.

headline: More Incubators Hatch Start-Ups
summary: Programs designed to help launch entrepreneurial ventures are expanding nationwide amid increased demand for the resources, services and counseling the programs typically provide for little or no cost.

headline: Chinese Stocks Fall on Tightening Fears
summary: Hong Kong and mainland Chinese shares slid as the fear of monetary tightening by Beijing resurfaced after economic data revealed consumer and property prices continued to rise on the mainland. Most Asian markets declined.

headline: Toyota Puts Crisis in the Rearview Mirror
summary: Consider Toyota's profit a reward for decades spent carefully building a brand.

headline: Australia Cuts Borrowing Forecast
summary: The Australian government sharply cut its projected borrowing requirement and mapped out a plan to more quickly pay down debt, as a fast-growing economy and rising revenue could push its budget back into surplus three years faster than expected.

headline: Greece to Request First Aid Tranche
summary: Greece will formally submit its request for the first tranche of aid from the European Union and expects to receive the first installment of financial support from the IMF on Wednesday.

headline: Hitachi Returns to Profit
summary: Japanese technology conglomerate Hitachi posted a profit in the January-March quarter, on a sharp recovery in consumer electronics and automotive systems.

headline: U.K. Industrial Production Jumps
summary: A sharp rise in U.K. industrial production in March, boosted in part by a weaker pound, could lead to an upward revision in first-quarter economic growth.

headline: Deutsche Post's Net Profit Jumps 85%
summary: German mail and logistics giant Deutsche Post said net profit surged, boosted by a $1.79 billion one-off gain related to the sale of Deutsche Postbank.

headline: Diageo Finance Chief to Exit
summary: Diageo's Chief Financial Officer Nick Rose will stand down at the company's annual shareholders meeting on Oct. 14 and be replaced by Deputy Finance Director Deirdre Mahlan.

headline: For Bets on Euro Bailout, Buy Japan or Asia
summary: There are two ways the European  Union's colossal bailout for its crisis-stricken sovereign borrowers could go:  well enough, or terribly. While it is too early to say which is more likely,  each outcome produces the same trading strategy for the euro: sell it.

headline: South African Strike Escalates
summary: The movement of commodities and fuel in South Africa may be halted after a second labor union said it would join a strike by thousands of workers at the country's freight rail, ports and pipelines.

headline: OPEC Ups Oil Demand Forecast
summary: OPEC said global oil demand was likely to grow more than previously expected, as China's resilient economy offsets persistent fears over some European countries.

headline: JA Solar Posts Profit
summary: Solar-cell maker JA Solar said its earnings rose as volume was higher than expected and revenue soared.

headline: Church & Dwight Profit Rises 28%
summary: Church & Dwight earnings rose 28% as the consumer-goods maker reported improved sales and margins.

headline: Agency Pushes Indian Telecom Deals
summary: India's telecommunications regulator Tuesday recommended lifting curbs on mergers and acquisitions to drive consolidation in an industry in which stiff competition and ultralow call charges are hurting operators.

headline: Fossil Profit Soars on Record Sales
summary: Fossil's earnings more than doubled as the watch and fashion-accessories retailer had record results and sees performance exceeding expectations.

headline: Carlsberg Swings to Profit
summary: Danish brewer Carlsberg swung to a first-quarter net profit, helped by improved margins in key regions.

headline: As a Deal Unravels, Is It Anarchy in the U.K.?
summary: It looked clear last Friday that the U.K. election had delivered the worst possible outcome for markets—yet somehow the country's political leaders have conspired to make a bad situation worse.

headline: Okinawa Timing: It's Complicated
summary: It doesn't look the third time's the charm for Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama and his long-simmering Okinawa policy.

summary: German utility E.ON reported a 7.3% drop in first-quarter net profit due in part to an impairment charge on recently divested U.S. power and gas operations, and maintained a forecast of flat to slightly higher full-year earnings.

headline: Toyota's Rivals Eat Prius Dust -- Again
summary: Prius sales in Japan are still as runaway as a sedan with a sticky pedal.

headline: Japan Vows to Cap Bond Sales
summary: Japan's finance minister pledged "utmost efforts" to keep the amount of new debt issuance in the next fiscal year from topping the current year's level, signaling his resolve to slow the country's debt binge amid widespread concern over public borrowing levels in industrialized countries.

headline: Peabody: Macarthur Bid Offers Value
summary: Peabody Energy said its reduced takeover offer for Australia's Macarthur Coal represented "compelling value" for the target company's shareholders.

headline: Malaysian Output Tops Forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial output expanded at a faster-than-expected pace in March, signaling a robust first quarter for the economy and strengthening expectations of a rate increase Thursday.

headline: Asciano Cuts $1 Billion From Asset Values
summary: Asciano Group said it will write down the value of its Australian infrastructure assets by around $1 billion, with the bulk of the impact felt by its container ports business ahead of Hutchison Whampoa's planned 2013 entry as a third domestic stevedore.

headline: A Difficult Coalition Either Way
summary: A number of the key stumbling blocks that could frustrate a Liberal Democrat deal with the Conservatives could also scupper a deal with Labour. On defence and immigration,

headline: A Case of 3 Feet High and Rising for Shinsei
summary: The just-ended fiscal year was a turnaround for Japanese banks -- except Shinsei.

headline: Bailout Battle Reshapes Arkansas Race
summary: The heated populism of the 2010 election campaign is reshaping the debate over financial regulation and ratcheting up the pressure on Wall Street.

headline: Little on Cable TV Helps Parents
summary: "How Parents Became Cool" (Personal Journal, April 28) is a sad commentary on modern-day parenting. Little, if anything, on cable television today is helping me educate my children and inculcate moral values.

headline: High-Stakes Battle for Macau Project
summary: One face-off could cost the backers of a $2.4 billion Macau casino-resort project—including two big-name U.S. investment firms—their shirts.

headline: Legg Mason Swings to a Profit
summary: Asset manager Legg Mason swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter profit, on a prior-year charge from eliminating all remaining structured-investment vehicles from its money-market funds.

headline: Are You There God? It's Me, Baseball
summary: In the debate over whether there are baseball Gods, Dallas Braden's perfect game scores one for the believers.

headline: Fed to Defend Loan Plan
summary: The Fed sought to pre-empt criticism of its decision to reopen a controversial lending program, arguing it was necessary to prevent Europe's crisis from reaching U.S. shores.

headline: Greek Rescue Leaves Problems Unsolved
summary: Europe's rescue plan for Greece has calmed markets and assured everyone that the ECB will lubricate the banking system and credit markets. That is welcome, but doesn't solve the underlying problem.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World Wide Top Stories for May 11

headline: Where Ladies Lunch
summary: The Carlyle Restaurant, an Upper East Side landmark, draws a lunchtime crowd of female regulars.

headline: Europe's Stressed Test
summary: Calming panicked markets is half the battle in any bailout. But as the U.S. found with efforts to rescue the banking system, lasting success depends on a plan's ability to address the root problems that spooked investors.

headline: Britain Now Sleepwalking to Disaster
summary: You have to hand it to Gordon Brown: He's persistent. Having lost the general election he announced that he plans to continue as Prime Minister to oversee the transition to a Labour successor. He has resigned, in order to stay on.

headline: Paterson Wins on Furloughs
summary: Lawmakers voted to furlough 100,000 state employees for a single day next week, giving the Paterson administration a significant victory in the battle over the budget.

headline: Shinsei Forecasts Loss for Year
summary: Shinsei Bank lowered its group net profit outlook to a loss for the fiscal year ended March, due to higher provisions for financing related to real-estate investments and its consumer-finance business.

headline: Treasury Prices Tumble
summary: U.S. government-bond yields shot higher, as the huge international package to support debt-laden euro-zone nations pulled the flight-to-quality bid out of the market.

headline: New Risks for Some Stomach Drugs
summary: Medications known as proton pump inhibitors, which suppress acid in the stomach, appear to be associated with fractures in postmenopausal women and with higher rates of bacterial infections.

headline: Rules Coming on 401(k) Advice
summary: A federal agency hopes to move forward with a regulation on investment advice for individual account plans, such as 401(k)s, within the next few months.

headline: Mets Don't Capitalize as Nationals Win 3-2
summary: The Mets left seven runners on base over the final four innings Monday, striking out a collective 11 times in a 3-2 loss to the Washington Nationals.

headline: Senators Seek Ban on Banks' Proprietary Trades
summary: Senate Democrats are proposing that proprietary trading activity by large banks be prohibited, and that a ban be placed on conflicts of interest within the banks.

headline: Small Loss at Clear Channel
summary: CC Media Holdings and its Clear Channel billboard operations reported narrower quarterly losses.

headline: RBS to Forfeit $500 Million in Fraud Case
summary: RBS agreed to pay $500 million to settle charges that ABN Amro, a Dutch bank it acquired in 2007, helped clients evade U.S. sanctions on countries accused of sponsoring international terrorism.

headline: Knives Out Over City's Sick-Pay Plan
summary: The City Council is weighing to require all city businesses to provide sick pay, a proposal that advocates laud as crucial to public health and opponents see as devastating to businesses.

headline: City Hospitals to Cut 500 More Jobs
summary: New York City's public hospital system plans to stanch a $1.2 billion budget gap in the next year's budget by laying off about 500 workers and ending contracts with "a significant number" of physicians.

headline: Healing Salt
summary: Indoor salt rooms have been popping up in cities across the U.S. as marketers tout salty air as a remedy for allergies, asthma, colds and even skin problems.

headline: New York Area Crime Blotter
summary: A roundup of area police and court activity.

headline: Why We Lie So Well
summary: New studies suggest that lying starts young—as young as 2 years old—and that what happens in our brains when we lie is different in adults than children.

headline: M.B.A. Job Market a Mixed Bag
summary: Overall, for business-school students in the class of 2010, finding a job has been a mixed experience. Many sectors haven't seen much hiring growth, but there are some signs that companies are beginning to ramp up.

headline: Fairholme Increases AIG Stake
summary: Fairholme Capital Management, already one of the largest private shareholders in AIG, bought more than 10 million additional shares in the bailed-out insurer in April.

headline: Teacher Grades Tied to Pupil Performance
summary: State and union officials have agreed to fundamentally change the way teachers are evaluated in New York, linking instructors' grades to student performance and making it easier to fire failing educators.

headline: U.S. Investigates Morgan Stanley
summary: U.S. prosecutors are investigating whether Morgan Stanley misled investors about mortgage-derivatives deals it helped design and sometimes bet against, in a step that intensifies Washington's scrutiny of Wall Street.

headline: $145 Billion and Counting
summary: Fannie and Freddie lose it all for you.

headline: Daredevil in Cockpit and Boardroom
summary: Paul Thayer, who died Thursday at age 90, was among the first to break the sound barrier in a Navy jet and engineered a turnaround at LTV.

headline: Dean Foods Profit, Shares Fall
summary: Dean Foods' CEO said some name-brand business might not bounce back as the company reported a 43% drop in first-quarter earnings. Its shares fell 28%.

headline: Merkel Won't Pursue Tax Cuts
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said in the wake of a harsh regional election defeat that her government won't pursue the tax cuts treasured by her coalition partners.

headline: Karzai, Clinton Emphasize Ties
summary: Hamid Karzai and Hillary Clinton attempted to put differences between the U.S. and Afghan governments behind them, saying that while they may have policy disagreements, such disputes do not reflect instability in the overall bilateral relationship.

headline: Keith McNally's Recipe on Parties
summary: When Keith McNally was named outstanding restaurateur at last week's James Beard Awards dinner, the unflappable Brit was nowhere to be found. "I don't like those things,' he says of ceremonies.

headline: Crude Rallies After Slump
summary: Crude-oil futures rebounded modestly from a steep four-day skid, boosted by a nearly $1 trillion rescue package for the euro-zone economies.

headline: U.S. Launches New Toyota Probe
summary: U.S. regulators launched a new investigation of Toyota on Monday, focusing on whether the company failed to report steering defects in certain models in 2004 and 2005.

headline: Zachary Karabell: The World's Dollar Drug
summary: Expect the greenback to remain the world's reserve currency, but that won't be a sign of U.S. strength.

headline: Our Species Rediscovers Its Cousins
summary: The new $20.7 million David H. Koch Hall of Human Origins marks the Smithsonian National Museum's centennial and provides a formidable overview of this still-developing story.

headline: Manhattan's Verdict on Kagan
summary: From the building where she grew up working in Democratic campaigns to the high school where she was a star, Elena Kagan's Manhattan basked in the glow of her Supreme Court nomination.

headline: No Agreement on California's Looming Pension Bust
summary: Regarding your editorial "Pension Bomb Ticks Louder" (April 27): A questionable study by Stanford's Institute for Economic Policy Research exaggerates the financing status of California's public pension funds.

headline: Data Show Drop in Police Frisking
summary: New York police stopped, questioned and sometimes frisked people 150,000 times in the first three months of the year, about 12.5% fewer times than the same period last year.

headline: More Deals for Start-Ups
summary: Big companies are back on the prowl for start-ups and the IPO market has improved, providing some relief to the battered venture-capital industry that invests in young firms.

headline: Treasury Announces $56 Billion in Auctions
summary: The Treasury will offer cash-management bills and other short-term securities.

headline: Neomi Rao:Elena Kagan and the 'Hollow Charade'
summary: Progressive views of judging are difficult to defend. That's why no recent nominee has tried.

headline: Moving Forward from Futenma
summary: The flap over an airbase in Okinawa points to larger problems in the U.S.-Japan security alliance.

headline: ECB Debt-Buying Sets a Precedent
summary: The ECB's move to buy debt of euro-zone governments, days after appearing to reject the idea, raises risks to its independence and reputation.

headline: U.K. Looks at Virgin Atlantic After British Air Case Fails
summary: A U.K. price-fixing case against British Airways former and current staff collapsed, and a regulator signaled it may pursue legal action against Virgin Atlantic, which had escaped prosecution by acting as whistle blower.

headline: Zimbabwe Court Acquits Mugabe Opponent
summary: Zimbabwe's High Court rejected terrorism and weapon charges against Roy Bennett, a white Zimbabwean farmer who is accused of plotting to overthrow the country's president, Robert Mugabe.

headline: A Friendship for the Pages
summary: Longtime pals Martin Amis and Christopher Hitchens make eyebrow-raising cameos in each other's new books.

headline: Show Stopper
summary: None

headline: Without Rules, Pot Dispensaries Flourish in L.A.
summary: City officials here are hoping that a new get-tough policy will finally allow them to crack down on the hundreds of medical marijuana dispensaries that have sprung up over the past few years.

headline: Nominee Draws Split Verdict on Hill
summary: Obama touted his Supreme Court pick, Elena Kagan, as a leader who can forge consensus on a divided court, while some conservatives questioned her lack of a judicial record.

headline: Fannie Mae Needs $8.4 Billion More
summary: Fannie Mae asked the government for an additional $8.4 billion in aid after posting an $11.5 billion loss for the first quarter

headline: KKR Files to Sell Shares in Move to NYSE
summary: The private-equity company plans to raise as much as $500 million by selling shares to the public.

headline: Working Triathlons Into the Fabric of a Busy Life
summary: In What's Your Workout?, Phaedra Hise walks readers through the exercise program followed by Kim Nelson, the chief executive of a Canadian packaging company. Ms. Nelson competes in triathlons and her training closely tracks the demands of that activity.

headline: Telecom Firms Thrive in Somalia
summary: Competition to supply phone service has stoked the nascent revival of Somalia's shattered economy.

headline: At Goldman, Conflicts as Opportunity
summary: The conflicts aren't the problem. The conflicts are the opportunity. Goldman Sachs has long had conflicts welcomed by investors clamoring to be involved with the Wall Street bank.

headline: Yen Loses as Euro Holds Its Own
summary: Growth-sensitive currencies such as the Brazilian real and the Australian dollar rallied, while the yen fell hard in reaction to the European rescue program.

headline: Beneficial Tax Change Sinks Some Deals
summary: Your editorial "Refloating Florida's Boats" (May 6)  describes the proposal to end the state of Florida's self-defeating policy on taxing yachts.  But in classic government fashion, the reported proposed effective date of the new tax rate is July 1. What does this mean for pending yacht transactions?

headline: Warning on Devices
summary: The FDA accused medical-device maker St. Jude Medical of violating the law by promoting and marketing its Epicor "surgical ablation" devices to treat a common heart-rhythm disorder without federal approval.
